elements.text: For each child, you will need a small circular paper plate, a craft stick, crayons, and tape.
and learned about different feelings. Let’s make something we can use to show people how we’re feeling.
In this activity, we’ll draw a happy face and a sad face on our paper plates. Then we’ll use the faces on our plates to show how we are feeling.

Pass out the materials and have children draw a happy face on one side of their paper plates and a sad face on the other side. They can add any other features to make their faces unique. Help children tape the craft sticks to the bottom of their paper plates. Model.

Bring up different situations that would cause children to have different feelings (e.g., losing a favorite stuffed animal, celebrating their birthday, etc.), and then have the children hold up the face that fits how they would feel in that situation.
Encourage children to use their Feelings Plates in Circle Time for the rest of the week when they want to express their feelings.
Invite children to talk about how often their feelings change during the day. Did they feel happy more, or sad more?

Ask children if they were ever surprised to see other children showing a different side of their Feeling Plates. Discuss how important it is to learn about identifying different feelings in other people.
Take note of children who are struggling to identify their feelings. Ask questions with obvious answers such as,
Do you feel happy or sad when you get presents?
Then have children show you how they would feel using the happy or sad side of their plates.

Encourage children to make Feelings Plates that show other emotions besides “happy” and “sad.” Possibilities include surprised, angry, excited, and disappointed. Children can use their new Feelings Plates in other activities.

Feelings Plates are helpful to multilingual learners who may have difficulty expressing their feelings in English. You may want to help them write the name of their feeling on both sides of the plate in English and, if possible, in their home language.

Children can use various art supplies to add more features to their Feelings Plates. They can either work to make them more into self-portraits (hair color, glasses, freckles, etc.) or they may just want to make them more colorful and imaginative. Just make sure the expression on the face is not obscured.

and talked about how we notice feelings in others. Noticing other people’s feelings helps us think about our own feelings. It also helps us to become better friends.
It’s good to recognize and name a feeling you think someone else is feeling and why you think they feel that way.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different  people and say how we think they are feeling. We will look at what they are doing in the picture to help us identify how they feel.
If you think you can name the feeling, raise your hand. I will call on as many children as I can.
Have children take turns picking one of the cards. Ask the group the question on the back of the card. Offer extra challenge and support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Continue the activity using the next card.
Talk About Identifying Feelings in Others

Discuss with children how hard it can be to correctly identify other people’s feelings. Ask children about some things they can do to figure out what someone else is feeling if they are not sure. Suggest questions they can ask.

For younger or developmentally delayed children, read aloud the Ask and Support sections of each card. Then, ask children to look closely at the picture on the front of the card and tell what else they notice about the person. Ask,
Do they look happy? Do they look scared?
As you introduce each feeling card, invite children to discuss what they would do if someone they know was feeling that way. Manage the discussion to make sure it stays positive and constructive.

Make sure multilingual learners are familiar with the words for the feelings that are represented on the cards. The fact that children will be acting out the feelings may level the playing field for children who are not yet English proficient. Monitor when children seem to be having difficulty understanding any of the words being used and provide support as needed.

Consider doing this activity in a larger space where children can use their bodies to convey the feeling on their card. They may want to use big movements to convey feelings such as happiness, excitement, and surprise.

and learned about many feelings that people have. We learned how to tell how the characters in the book were feeling by looking at the children’s faces and what they were doing.
In this activity, we will look at different pictures and say if we think the person in the picture looks happy or sad.
Ask children to give a thumbs-up if the picture shows someone who is happy, and thumbs-down if the person looks sad. Model.
Show a card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Invite children to talk about all of the different feelings they learned about in
and in the pictures. Encourage children to use as many describing words as possible as they talk about when they felt the same way.
“Happy” feelings can make us smile. And “sad” feelings can make us cry. Discuss the importance of expressing all feelings, even the ones that might make us feel sad.

If children are struggling to identify whether the feeling they see in the picture is happy or sad, talk with them about the expressions on the people’s faces. Ask them if they see a frown or a smile. Encourage children to use Feelings Plates from the Day 1 activity.

Encourage children to participate in peer-to-peer conversations about “happy” versus “sad” feelings, with each child taking two turns in the conversation. Remind children that while one person is talking, the other person should be listening.

Be sensitive to cultural differences that may come up during this activity. Provide extra support to English learners who may have an understanding of what’s happening in the picture but be unfamiliar with the words for that feeling. When different feeling words come up, make sure you write them down for the children to see, and review the meanings as necessary.

Provide paper and crayons. After looking at a card, have children draw a picture that shows the feeling you just discussed. There is no right or wrong here. Some children’s drawings may be representational, and some may be quite abstract. Invite volunteers to share their drawings with the group.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
If You’re Happy and You Know It
and then we sang a song. In the song, we learned about different actions that go with different feelings. Do you remember which action you do when you are happy?
In this activity, we will look at picture cards of people doing different actions. Then we will talk about how we think they are feeling.
As you show the picture cards, ask children to give a thumbs-up if they know what the person in the picture is feeling.
Show one picture card, say the details, and then ask the question on the back of the card. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of the card to extend the conversation.
Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Remind children about the different actions they saw on the poster. Revisit different actions from the picture cards. Invite children to talk about times when they’ve had feelings like the ones shown on the picture cards. Did they do the actions like the people in the pictures or did they do different actions? Ask about the different actions they showed.
Show children the “happy” picture card and then ask,
Do you cry when you are happy?
Then show the “sad” picture card. Ask,
Do you clap your hands when you are sad?
Encourage children to use as many describing words as possible to talk about the different actions.
Have children make a new action that shows one of the feelings shown on the picture cards. Encourage children to explain why they chose that action.

Young children need guidance to help interpret their feelings and emotions and to interact appropriately with others. Multilingual learners sometimes need extra help since they may lack the language skills to convey their emotions.

Have children exaggerate all of the actions for the feelings they saw on the picture cards so that they are broad movements. Working with feelings at this age lends itself to movement exploration, and some children may be more comfortable sharing their feelings in this way rather than using words.
